references: The notations used in this paper are listed in Table I.

We discuss SlimFL and global model aggregation in further detail. SlimFL is denoted by the symbols shown in Table I. Algorithm 4 describes the fundamental SlimFL operations. The network consists of K𝐾K devices that are linked through wireless connections to a parameter server. Each device uses SC whilst communicating with the server, whereas the server uses SD. To be more descriptive, k𝑘k-th device has a local dataset Zk∈𝒁superscript𝑍𝑘𝒁Z^{k}\in\bm{Z} and an SNN parameter θksuperscript𝜃𝑘\theta^{k} with two width configurations. Across devices, the global data 𝒁𝒁\bm{Z} may be IID or non-IID. Each SNN θksuperscript𝜃𝑘\theta^{k} is subdivided into an LH θk⊙Ξdirect-productsuperscript𝜃𝑘Ξ\theta^{k}\odot\Xi and a RH segment θk⊙Ξ−1direct-productsuperscript𝜃𝑘superscriptΞ1\theta^{k}\odot\Xi^{-1}, where Ξ=Ξ1ΞsubscriptΞ1\Xi=\Xi_{1} and Ξ−1=Ξ2−Ξ1superscriptΞ1subscriptΞ2subscriptΞ1\Xi^{-1}=\Xi_{2}-\Xi_{1}.
Superposition training is used to train the k𝑘k-th local device (lines 4–9), which is expressed as (3).
The local device transmits to the server the SC-encoded local model θksuperscript𝜃𝑘\theta^{k}.
Each local device transmits two messages (i.e., LH and RH segments), each with a distinct transmission power P1subscript𝑃1P_{1} and P2subscript𝑃2P_{2} relative to P1≫P2much-greater-thansubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1}\gg P_{2}.
The uniform random variable ρ∈[0,1]𝜌01\rho\in[0,1] is sampled for user k𝑘k as ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k}. The sampled ρksubscript𝜌𝑘\rho_{k} and the decoding success probability p1subscript𝑝1p_{1}, p2subscript𝑝2p_{2} are used as a criterion for whether LH and RH are successfully decoded. It is identical to calculate (9).
In accordance with (9), after reception, the server can successively decode using SD and obtain: (i) a 0.5x model if χ≥c/(P1/u′−P2)𝜒𝑐subscript𝑃1superscript𝑢′subscript𝑃2\chi\geq c/(P_{1}/u^{\prime}-P_{2}) (lines 15–17) is satisfied; (ii) 1.01.01.0x model if the channel fading gain satisfies χ≥max⁡{c/(P1/u′−P2),c/(P2/u′)}𝜒𝑐subscript𝑃1superscript𝑢′subscript𝑃2𝑐subscript𝑃2superscript𝑢′\chi\geq\max\{c/(P_{1}/u^{\prime}-P_{2}),c/(P_{2}/u^{\prime})\} (lines 18–20); and (iii) otherwise it obtains no model. As a result, the RH segments from 𝖥𝖥\mathsf{F} of devices and the LH segments from 𝖧∪𝖥𝖧𝖥\mathsf{H}\cup\mathsf{F} of devices are combined by the server.

To show the effectiveness of the proposed SlimFL, we consider a classification task with the Fashion MNIST (FMNIST) image dataset [37]. The impact of other datasets such as the CIFAR-10 and MNIST datasets will be discussed in VI-E. The dataset is randomly sharded and distributed across devices. Following [38], the non-IIDness of the data distribution is modeled using a Dirichlet distribution with its concentration parameter α∈{0.1,1.0,10}𝛼0.11.010\alpha\in\{0.1,1.0,10\}, where the higher α𝛼\alpha implies the more non-IID data distribution as illustrated in Fig 2. For numerical experiments, we adopt the light model of slimmable MobileNet, i.e., UL-MobileNet111This paper utilizes Ultra-Light MobileNet (UL-MobileNet) under the consideration of the limited computing capacity of local.It follows MobileNet architecture [39]. UL-MobileNet consists of five convolution layers activated by the ReLU6 function, average pooling function, and linear layer.. We consider a single communication round consisting of a pair of uplink and downlink transmissions for each local training iteration. The communication channels over different devices are orthogonal in both uplink and downlink. The Rayleigh fading gain χ𝜒\chi for each channel realization follows an exponential distribution χ∼Exp​(1)similar-to𝜒Exp1\chi\sim\textsf{Exp}(1) [28]. The corresponding communication and neural network hyperparameters are summarized in Table II.
We adopt Vanilla FL as a comparison technique. Vanilla FL is widely used FL technique (i.e., FedAvg) with a fixed-width SNN model without leveraging SC nor SD. We consider three Vanilla FL schemes as listed follows:

We design additional simulations to verify SlimFL works in more realistic channel models (e.g., Rician fading [30] and Two-wave with diffuse power fading (TWDP) [41]).
In indoor wireless communication, Rician fading is superior than Rayleigh fading. In addition, TWDP is used in air, space or maritime wireless communication, where the channel fading is worse than Rayleigh [42]. We simulate Rician fading with K𝐾K-factor 3.53.53.5, where the fading follows Rician distributions χ∼Rice​(0.5577,0.2106)similar-to𝜒Rice0.55770.2106\chi\sim\mathrm{Rice}(0.5577,0.2106). (K,Δ)𝐾Δ(K,\Delta)-factor of TWDP fading is set to (3.5,0.1)3.50.1(3.5,0.1). All communication settings without fading effect are identical to Table II. Fig. 11 is the result of the simulation. As shown in Fig. 11, the top-1 accuracy is found to be high in the order of Rayleigh fading, TWDP fading, and Rician fading channel models. SlimFL-1.0x always outperforms SlimFL-0.5x. Thus, SlimFL performs well in a variety of channel models.

Thus far, we have evaluated SlimFL’s performance after training using 1,00010001,000 epochs. We estimate the energy consumption till convergence in this section. Numerical convergence in training is defined as the point at which the standard deviation (std) of test accuracy falls below a predefined threshold and the lowest test accuracy exceeds the average test accuracy in 100100100 consecutive rounds. To assess model convergence, we establish the reference values for the mean μ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜇𝖱𝖾𝖿\mu_{\mathsf{Ref}} as 80%percent8080\% and σ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜎𝖱𝖾𝖿\sigma_{\mathsf{Ref}} as 7.25%percent7.257.25\%, respectively. Convergence occurs when the average Top-1 accuracy for 100100100 consecutive epochs is greater than μ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜇𝖱𝖾𝖿\mu_{\mathsf{Ref}} and the average std is less than σ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜎𝖱𝖾𝖿\sigma_{\mathsf{Ref}}.
With this convergence criterion, Table VI compares the overall energy costs of SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.5x until convergence, based on the communication and processing energy costs per round in Table IV. As shown in Table VI, harsh non-IIDness (α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1) with poor channel conditions makes FL convergence hard. SlimFL, on average, produces a 3.63.63.6x reduction in total computing costs and a 2.92.92.9x reduction in total communication costs until their convergences. In addition, Fig. 3 shows the energy efficiency results corresponding to accuracy. As shown in Fig. 3(a), SlimFL requires only the 32.63%percent32.6332.63\% of Vanilla FL-1.5x’s total communication cost for model convergence. Similarly, the computing cost for SlimFL is the 44.37%percent44.3744.37\% of Vanilla FL-1.5x’s as shown in Fig. 3(b). This increased energy efficiency is according to SlimFL’s faster convergence even in non-IID and/or bad channel circumstances caused by SC and SD.

references:
Between ten devices and a server, the total quantity of data communicated is 205.8205.8205.8MBytes for SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.0x, and 102.9102.9102.9MBytes for Vanilla FL-0.5x under ideal channel conditions (i.e., always successful decoding). We investigate the efficiency of communication resources in both good and bad channel conditions to validate the effectiveness of SC and SD.
The experimental result for this subsection is presented in Table V, which shows that SlimFL delivers up to 3.52%percent3.523.52\% fewer dropped bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x when SC and SD are being used.
SlimFL enjoys the benefits mentioned above while consuming only half of the transmission power and bandwidth compared to Vanilla FL-1.5x, as presented in Table V, corroborating its communication efficiency. Because a part of the transmission power of SlimFL is allocated to 0.5x models, SlimFL decodes less than 1.0x model bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x. In return, SlimFL receives not only 1.0x models but also 0.5x models simultaneously. The additional received 0.5x models coincide with the LH parts of the 1.0x models, which improve the accuracy and convergence speed of both 0.5x and 1.0x models.

Thus far, we have evaluated SlimFL’s performance after training using 1,00010001,000 epochs. We estimate the energy consumption till convergence in this section. Numerical convergence in training is defined as the point at which the standard deviation (std) of test accuracy falls below a predefined threshold and the lowest test accuracy exceeds the average test accuracy in 100100100 consecutive rounds. To assess model convergence, we establish the reference values for the mean μ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜇𝖱𝖾𝖿\mu_{\mathsf{Ref}} as 80%percent8080\% and σ𝖱𝖾𝖿subscript𝜎𝖱𝖾𝖿\sigma_{\mathsf{Ref}} as 7.25%percent7.257.25\%, respectively. With this convergence criterion, Table VI compares the overall energy costs of SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.5x until convergence, based on the communication and processing energy costs per round in Table IV. As shown in Table VI, harsh non-IIDness (α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1) with poor channel conditions makes FL convergence hard. SlimFL, on average, produces a 3.63.63.6x reduction in total computing costs and a 2.92.92.9x reduction in total communication costs until their convergences. In addition, Fig. 3 shows the energy efficiency results corresponding to accuracy. As shown in Fig. 3(a), SlimFL requires only the 32.63%percent32.6332.63\% of Vanilla FL-1.5x’s total communication cost for model convergence. Similarly, the computing cost for SlimFL is the 44.37%percent44.3744.37\% of Vanilla FL-1.5x’s as shown in Fig. 3(b). references: SlimFL and Vanilla FL both achieve high accuracy when channel conditions are good, as shown in Fig. 5 and Table VII. When the channel condition deteriorates from good to poor, however, as shown in Fig. 5(c,f) and Table VII, Vanilla FL1.0x’s maximum accuracy at α=10𝛼10\alpha=10 declines from 868686 to 828282 percent. SlimFL-1.0x, on the other hand, retains its maximum accuracy of 878787 percent at α=10𝛼10\alpha=10 in both good and bad channel conditions. Additionally, at α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1, SlimFL-1.0x outperforms Vanilla FL-1.0x by 18%percent1818\% in terms of top-1 accuracy, despite the fact that Vanilla FL-1.0x consumes more communication and computing resources. Additionally, as the channel condition degrades, the std of Vanilla FL-1.0x’s top-1 accuracy increases by up to 59%percent5959\%, while SlimFL’s std increases by just 31%percent3131\%. These findings show SlimFL’s resistance to poor channels conditions, as well as its resistance to non-IID data distributions (low α𝛼\alpha) and communication efficiency.

SlimFL-0.5x has a stable convergence under α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1 condition, as indicated in Fig. 5(d–f) and Table VII In poor channel conditions and with the non-IID distribution (α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1), Vanilla FL-0.5x and Vanilla FL-1.0x display the std of 8.38.38.3 and 9.29.29.2. On the other hand, SlimFL-0.5x and SlimFL-1.0x both demonstrate the std of 2.42.42.4 and 2.92.92.9 with top-1 accuracy. This propensity persists even when α=1𝛼1\alpha=1, α=10𝛼10\alpha=10 are prevalent. SlimFL-1.0x and SlimFL-0.5x have a smaller coefficient of variation than Vanilla FL-1.0x and Vanilla FL-0.5x. This accentuates SlimFL’s robustness to non-IID data on poor channels.

To verify the impact on heterogeneous computing capacities of devices, we investigate six-width configurations (e.g., 1/6x, 2/6x, ⋯⋯\cdots, and 6/6x).
First, we train SNNs with the default settings of SlimFL (α=10𝛼10\alpha=10, K=10𝐾10K=10, σ2=−30​dBsuperscript𝜎230dB\sigma^{2}=-30\text{dB}). Then, we measure top-1 accuracy and calculate FLOPS.
Its specification is presented in Table VIII.
Second, we investigate the dynamic width adaptation to the device, which has a time-varying theoretical peak performance of the CPU, denoted as RpeaksubscriptRpeak\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}} (MFLOPS). We set Rpeak∈[20,230]subscriptRpeak20230\textsf{R}_{\textsf{peak}}\in[20,230] (MFLOPS).
Lastly, we calculate the number of image processing per second (IPS) by the following metric:
